Clive Wynne-Candy.Action: No direct actions or statements in excerpt; the unit and officers have done all the proper things, camouflaged vehicles, taken advantage of terrain, dug in for four days.
Leaves the Royal Bathers' Club an hour before an urgent message arrives, possibly missing timely communication.

Responds patiently to being awoken abruptly and to confusing situation.
Looks around for help showing vulnerability but remains composed.
No hostile reaction to being taken prisoner; instead seems to maintain calm demeanor.
Slow to fully wake and comprehend situation; confused and disoriented when confronted by captors.
Maintains calm under surprising and threatening circumstances, attempts to understand the events.
Attempts to assert authority despite being overwhelmed and caught off-guard.
His general's office is invaded and his official equipment (code case) is taken by unauthorized militia without immediate or visible resistance.

Reacting with disbelief and a frown to the possibility that their own men talked under interrogation, showing critical thinking and concern about internal security.
Shows critical thinking by considering the indication of prisoners cracking and reflects on the conduct of the enemy, demonstrating insight into the situation.
Relies on Van Zijl to read the German paper and does not read it himself despite understanding German is involved.
Walks down the line of prisoners, examining each closely and addresses them directly.
Asks prisoners if they know an officer and if they speak English, showing attention to communication.
Tells prisoners that they don't use harsh methods like their captors but have means to get what they want.
Listens carefully to the enemy appeal, remains composed and grimly smiles, indicating calm assessment.
Identifies rumour of the Kaiser's abdication and shows thoughtful consideration, demonstrating awareness of relevant strategic information.
Engages directly with prisoners, tries to identify officers among them and elicit information, showing proactive interrogation skills.
Acknowledges lack of immediate responses but persists in communication attempts, indicating patience and methodical approach.
Uses an authoritative tone to gain cooperation from prisoners, reflects command presence and confidence.
Blusters and bellows aggressively at prisoner, demanding answers and not showing patience or tolerance.
Refuses dinner politely but engages mildly with Van Zijl, sharing a light complaint about the food and weather.
Blusters aggressively at the prisoner and fails to get useful information, showing impatience and lack of control in interrogation.
Delegates interrogating the prisoners to Van Zijl after failing to make progress himself, recognizing limits and passing responsibility.
Displays social awareness and good humor when declining dinner and engaging Van Zijl in light conversation before departure.
Laughs amiably and jokes with others before departing; others smile at him warmly.
Shows tolerance and affection as noted by Van Zijl calling him 'Good old Sugar Candy' and remarking he has a tender heart.
Jokes confidently about the likelihood of the enemy situation resolving before returning, indicating awareness of circumstances and calmness.
Commands Murdoch with light humor about his repeated loss of direction, yet instructs him to carry on, showing balanced leadership and situational control.

No indication of gathering intelligence from prisoners despite going to see them (Van Zijl mentions he got 'not a sausage' from them), suggesting limited effectiveness in interrogation or exploiting opportunities.
No action or presence in this excerpt; passive omission from the situation.
Calls for help, tries to engage the sentry and others to assist in freeing the car from mud, encourages effort despite difficulty.
Shouts loudly to get sentry's attention, quickly assesses that the car is stuck, calls for help, and orders pushing to try to get unstuck.
Despite efforts to get out of mud, fails to find an immediate solution and continues struggling with inadequate means.
Indomitably decides to walk to the village himself and instructs Murdoch to follow after a truck.
Engages respectfully with the sentry, asking for guidance and following directions without sarcasm or contempt.
Decides to walk to the village alone despite difficulties, takes initiative to gather information by questioning the sentry, and gives clear instructions to Murdoch.
Struggles physically, stumbling over rails while trying to enter the R.T.O. hut, suggesting some lack of ease or preparedness in the terrain.

Acts with some impatience (being described as 'having kittens'), indicating possible frustration during the radio communication issues.

Interrupts and corrects radio operator, showing frustration but revealing prior knowledge of the route.
Displays frustration with wartime inefficiency but speaks with humor and openness when asking a young soldier for food.

Dismisses urgent news of German armistice talks as propaganda without seeking verification or adapting to new intelligence.
Recognizes systemic inefficiencies in war logistics and expresses frustrated awareness of supply and operational shortcomings.
Responds to chaotic situation by focusing on basic personal needs (asking for food) rather than taking immediate strategic or leadership actions.
Engages politely and cordially with R.T.O., asks his name and origin, showing interest and friendliness.

Engages with the R.T.O. to find a suitable place to rest and eat, showing resourcefulness and communication skills.
Clarifies what the 'Crown of Thorns' is by questioning rather than making assumptions, demonstrating intellectual curiosity and caution.

Expresses mild frustration at unable to get a train but quickly adapts to the alternative transport arrangement without further complaint.

Repeats questions impatiently multiple times to Murdoch, showing frustration and inability to effectively manage the situation or elicit useful information.
Demonstrates awareness of timing constraints (train leaves at 10:30) and the need to reach Ami-le-Bon early for additional time, indicating planning and foresight.
Expresses frustration by telling Murdoch to stop talking like a 'parrot', showing difficulty in communication and perhaps a loss of patience, which may undermine effective coordination.

Encourages Theo not to hang up the phone and insists on seeing him before he leaves; arranges dinner including the Camp Commander and military transport officer; invites Theo to have a glass of port before leaving England.

Encourages Theo that he will feel different and better when back home, showing empathy for his situation.

Engages in reassurance without dismissing concerns, maintaining diplomacy, yet does not offer concrete solutions to prisoners' fears about occupation.
Speaks confidently about the impossibility of reconciling with Germany if they are robbed and humiliated; appeals to common understanding through reading the English papers.
Exhibits pride and warmth while seeing off Theo, showing social confidence and diplomatic grace in a tense environment.
Engages in a public farewell with warmth and informal humor, maintaining morale and camaraderie.

Comforts and reassures a friend about post-war recovery, showing hope and steady optimism.
Pauses and questions his own habit (humming), indicating self-awareness and lightheartedness rather than uncertainty.
Encourages open communication and expresses solidarity by stating 'If you are a friend, our precautions are your precautions and our interests are your interests.'
His wife stayed at his side despite her wish to return to England, showing loyalty and support during difficult times.
Remembers with fondness and respect the people who cheered returning prisoners of war, showing appreciation and warmth toward others.
Recollects meeting an Englishman who became his greatest friend despite limited contact over many years, indicating capacity for sincere friendship.
Notes that neither of his sons came to his wife's funeral, possibly indicating estrangement or lack of family warmth.
Decides to stay at his post despite personal loss, believing leaving would let down his country in its greatest need.
Acknowledges the presence of people with no talent or desire to work or learn within his professional environment.

Comes to testify on behalf of Theo promptly and confidently despite disruptive circumstances; appears self-assured and commanding presence.
